\begin{document}

\maketitle
\tableofcontents
\phantomsection\label{index::doc}


The PyQG team aims to build a ``git generation'' community quasi-geostrophic model in Python. Ideally, PyQG will be a tool that is easy-to-use, high-level and unit-tested.

Please note the following about this project:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
PyQG is in its birth, and its a side-project of its core developers.

\item {} 
...

\end{itemize}


\chapter{Requirements}
\label{index:welcome-to-pyqg-s-documentation}\label{index:requirements}
PyQG assumes you have python installed on your computer. The only strict requirement is \emph{numpy}, but it is convenient to install \emph{matplotlib}, \emph{scipy} and \emph{mkl}. We strongly encourage you to get python from pre-cooked distributions such as \href{https://store.continuum.io/cshop/anaconda/}{anaconda} and \href{https://www.enthought.com/products/canopy/}{canopy}

To speed-up calculations, you can install
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
pyfftw

\item {} 
...

\end{itemize}

These are easily installed in anaconda or canopy. For example

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{} }conda install pyfftw
\end{Verbatim}


\chapter{Installation}
\label{index:installation}
You can download \href{https://github.com/rabernat/pyqg}{PyQG} form its repository. If you use git, you can simply clone it

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{} }git clone https://github.com/rabernat/pyqg.git
\end{Verbatim}

You should install PyQG on your system:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{} }python setup.py install
\end{Verbatim}

If you want to make changes in the code, set up the development mode:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{} }python setup.py develop
\end{Verbatim}
